title: R40913
content: The United States has a history of relying on domestic energy sources, but growing industrialization and population led to increased dependence on foreign energy in the 20th century. Federal efforts have focused on increasing energy independence, promoting energy efficiency, and developing renewable energy sources. These programs have been periodically reauthorized and redesigned to adapt to changing economic conditions and national interests. Since 2005, Congress has enacted major energy laws to establish, expand, or modify energy efficiency and renewable energy programs. The Department of Energy operates the most programs, with others found in the Departments of Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, Labor, Housing and Urban Development, Veterans Affairs, and Small Business Administration. The report outlines federal programs and provisions for energy efficiency, conservation, and renewable energy RDD&D administered by various agencies including the Department of Energy, Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, Labor, HUD, VA, and SBA. Incentives are summarized with references to agency websites and budget information sources. The curr_chunk discusses federal renewable energy and energy efficiency incentives, including programs such as Clean Renewable Energy Bonds and Energy Efficiency and Conservation Block Grants. It also mentions expired programs like the Energy Efficient Appliance Rebate Program. Federal renewable energy and energy efficiency incentives include programs like Clean Renewable Energy Bonds, Energy Efficiency and Conservation Block Grants, Energy Efficient Appliance Rebate Program, and Renewable Energy Grants (1603 Program).
